CROSS-COUNTRY TEAM
VICTORS.
Defeat Delaware College and Maryland State—Prospects for S. A.
A. A. Championship
Bright.

Johns Hopkins' Cross-Country
Team defeated Delaware College
and Maryland State at Newark,
Del., Saturday. The scores were:
Johns Hopkins, 26 Delaware, 32;
while Maryland State was left in
the lurch, with a total of 87
points. The race ivas run over
newly-tarred roads and was a
gruelling test for the men who will
represent Hopkins at the S. A. I.
A. A. cross-country championship
next week.
So fast was the pace set by Delaware's star runner, Booth, who
was runner-up to Larry Shields in
the inter-allied games, and so
• keenly was the race contested by
Hopkins and Delaware that Maryland State's best runner could get
only eleventh place. Booth covered the course in 28 minutes and
52 seconds, thus bettering his own
time by nearly a minute. Millikin,
Hopkins' captain, ran a corking
,
race, finally losing to the longlegged Booth, but beating out Wilson, the Delaware captain. Wilson was hard pushed for third by
Milligan, whose mile-running last
year marked him as a future star
for Hopkins.
Right on Milligan's heels were
two Hopkins rookies, Holsopple
and Somerville, who ran a dead
heat for fifth place. Following
two Delaware men came Ray
Hazeltine, who, had it not been
for a stitch he developed in the
last mile, would have finished
nearer the van. Cannon, who had
(Continued on page 4, col. 2)

VOTE FOR THE NONATHLETIC FEE.
The proposed Non-Athletic
Fee, the conditions of which
appear elsewhere in THE
NEWS-LETTER, will be voted
on by the student-body at the
weekly mass-meeting. All
Hopkins students are urged
to read and consider carefully the provisions of this
Fee which, if passed, will
prove of great value to the
advancement of the NonAthletic activities at Homevood.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 16, 1920

HOPKINS 41

ST. JOHNS 0

Worst Defeat Ever Administered to Cadets by Black
and Blue—Markell and Jones Star for Hopkins
Freshman Defeat Severn in Preliminary Game
The Black and Blue football team, displaying a crushing attack
and a stone wall defense, last Saturday beat St. John's, 41 to 0, and
sent them home with the worst defeat they have ever received from
Hopkins.
Before the game was five minutes old it became clear that it was
merely a question of how many points Hopkins would roll up, for the
Cadets were unable either to halt their opponents' offensive or to do
anything at all with the ball themselves. The St. John's rooters were
forced to display all their enthusiasm before the game.
Preceding the Hopkins steam roller and the coffin with its funeral
procession, they marched upon the field with a great show of confidence,
but to no avail; from the referee's first whistle the day belonged to
Hopkins.
John Markell and Elmer Jones occupied the limelight most of the
time,for each one was in the game with all he had. Nothing could stop
Markell when, with fine interference, he skirted the ends or skimmed
the tackles for gains that were seldom less than 10 yards. Such work
would have been enough to'set him apart, but in addition he outpunfed
the St. John's hooters, threw a forward pass, intercepted one and
knocked down several more.
Jones also had little difficulty in smashing through the Cadets'
line for long gains, and when St. John's ,had the ball, showed what was,
without a doubt, the best defensive game he has ever played, and that is
saying a good deal. The outstanding play of the game was his dash
of 60 yards through the St. John's team at the beginning of the second
half.
The play of the Black and Blue
was anything but individual; Hopkins had a team on the field, a
team that worked as a unit and
made few mistakes. The line held
the Cadets to two first downs, and
time and again seemed to bury
the Annapolitans under a heap of
black jerseys, while the backfield
rolled up six touchdowns and 25
first downs with a display of coordination and snioothness they
have never, before possessed. Perfect interference was the only
thing that made possible many of
the long gains, and in this interference Jones played a leading
Part. Forward passes, although
not at all needed, were used effectively.• Markell's punts were
long, and the ends were down under them with a speed that caught
the receiver before he had a chance
to move. There were no weak
spots in the machine.
The game was only a succession
of marches down the field by the
Black, and Blue steam roller,
which always ended in a score,
even though temporarily halted.
Gaining the ball in the first few
minutes, Hopkins worked it to the
goal line, only to lose it by what

seemed a poor decision. In a, moment, however, they were right
back, and Jones had scored the
first coUnter. In the second quarter he again carried the ball over,
after Markell's 20-yard plunge
through the line had placed it under the goal posts. Twice more
Hopkins threatened to score, but
each time was robbed of the opportunity to roll up the count by
a fumble.
The second half saw a great
weakening in the St. John's team.
Markell and Jones continued to
reel off the first downs, aided now
and then by a forward pass. Several times St. John's held, but it
was only for the moment, and
soon the ball was deep in their territory again.
Hopkins had
amassed 41 points, and was on its
way to another when the game
ended.
The contest with the Cadets
marked still another stage in the
gradual development of the Black
and Blue, which has been marked
in the last three games. If this
improvement continues, Western
Maryland has little chance next
Saturday and State will have its

Tentative Petition Drawn Up—Criticism and Alterations Invited.
Petition to be Presented at
Mass-meeting.

The following tentative petition
has been drawn up to be presented
at a student mass-meeting on
Thursday, November 18. It provides for a non-athletic fee to be
levied in the same manner as the
present athletic fee, and provides
for a central control of all the non'athletic activities, at the same
time taking away from these activities none of their rightful
powers. Such a plan has been
worked with great success at
many other institutions. •
The plan is purely tentative,
and it is hoped that it will call
forth a great deal of discussion between now and the mass-meeting.
A.11 who are interested and desire
to suggest alterations or additions
to the proposal are urged to leave
them at the NEWS-LETTER office
before 5 P. M. Wednesday.
If passed by the student-body at
the mass-meeting the revised petition will be presented to the
Trustees, with a request urging
them to take action on it as soon
as possible. The petition in its
tentative form is as follows:
"Resolved, That we, the studentbody of Johns Hopkins University,
request the Board of Trustees to
establish a fee of $10 to be devoted
to non-athletic activities, which
fee is to be paid by each student
upon entrance to the University,
as is the present athletic fee.
"That this fee shall be turned
over to the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, to be divided among the

NOTICE.
.Beginning with the issue
of Monday, November 15, the
Johns Hopkins Daily Bulletin will be found in the Y. M.
a A. office, the Postoffice, and
before the bulletin boards in

present, of having the Bulletin placed in each student's
postoffice box, will henceforth
be discontinued in order to
relieve the congestion in the
Postoffice.

ATHLETIC STORE MOVES.
The Johns Hopkins Athletic
Store has just been moved to
larger and more convenient quarters in the Students' Activity
Building in the old barber shop
on the ground floor. It is here
that one can buy athletic goods
of all varieties and the best quality. McCallister's sporting goods
are on display there and whatever
the main store has can be gotten
easily and quickly. The Athletic
Association maintains this store
in order that men can get their
supplies which are needed without the trouble of going downtown to get them. Purchasing
things there also helps to put a
man through college. It is always
open from 12.30 to 1 and after
laboratory in the afternoon.
Joe Thompson has a large supply of megaphones substantially
made up in black and blue. Every
man ought to have one of these to
assist in the rooting at these next
two games. Those who are working for track can secure sweat
shirts and winter running clothes
which will surpass any that can
be bought downtown. All Hopkins men should look into the supply at the Athletic Store before
Purchasing elsewhere — it will
help both.

In a recent letter to the Unigersity Y. M. C. A., President
3utler of Columbia said:
"It seems to me that any University which does not give proper
and central place to the religious
life and religious influence can
hardly claim to be an educational
institution. It may give most excellent instruction and it may
foster research; but with that
lack it will never be able to truly
educate."

TO INSPECT UNIT TODAY.
The E. 0. T. C. Unit will be inspected today by two distinguished
officers from Washington, Maj.Gen. William G. Haan and Col.
Frank J. Morrow. General Haan
is Assistant to Chief of Staff, War
Plans Division, and commanded
the 32d Division during the war.
Colonel Morrow is in the War
Plans Division of the General
Staff. The Unit will have classroom work during the inspection
and no formal review or military
exercises are contemplated.

LECTURE ON "ISLAM IN SYRIA."

PROF. FRANK MORLEY
Secretary

Mr. Fedder read a very interesting paper on "Pseudo-Messiahs
and their relation to Zionists,"
before the Zionist Study Circle, at
their meeting last Friday. Next
week, Mr. Barowy will talk on
"Emancipation, Haskalah and.Reform Movelnents in Judaism." On
Tuesday, Mr. Peretz will address
the Hebrew-speaking Circle in
Hebrew, on "Hebrew Education."
The public is invited to be present.

The first of a course of six lectures on "The Secret Cults of
Syria," "Islam in Syria," was delivered last Friday by Frederick
Jones Bliss, Ph.D., in the Civil
Engineering Hall.
Dr. Bliss
traced the history of the Arab conquest of Syria, the conversion of
portions of the population to Mohammedanism,_and the subsequent
development of Islam in the country. He als dwelt at some length

day, November 10, three new men
appeared on the campus — men
whom the students should become
acquainted with from whose experience in the various fields of
life they should profit.
Dr. W. H. Morgan who leads
the Freshman class group, was
at the age of nine, a mill boy in
an Ohio steel mill. At the age of
majority he could neither read nor
write. His self-education began
with the finding of a history and a
geography. Today he has the degrees of A. B., A. M., Ph. D. and
D. D. Formerly pastor of one of
the largest Methodist Episcopal
churches in the world, Calvary
Church, New York City, he is now
pastor of the First M. E. Church
of this city.
Mr. Carey for 30 years treasurer of the Provident Savings
Bank subsequently with the Morriss Apartment Corporation, has
had wide experience with men in
the business world and is ably
fitted to make the Senior-Junior •
Forum interesting and profitable.
Mr. Morriss for 38 years general secretary of the Central Y. M.
C. A., has given his life to work
with and for young men. One of
the most widely influential men
in Baltimore life, he knows men
and understands sympathetically
their questions.
It is hoped that the studentbody will avail itself of this opportunity of extending its knowledge and interest in the life and
work of the world.

The NEWS-LETTER wishes to annonce the promotion of C. Warwick Perkins,'21; Frank R. Smith,
'21, and Norville E. Miller, '22,
from Junior to Associate Editors.
The NEWS-LETTER also wishes to
announce the election of Lawrence
B. Fenneman,'23, to the Editorial
Board as Junior Editor.

OLD - TIME "PEP"
DISPLAYED.
Much of the old-time "pep" and
spirit of rivalry against St. Johns
was manifested by the huge bonfire at Homewood and the parade
through the town in which some
300 students participated. The
bonfire and parade were in accord
with old Hopkins' traditions. The
enthusiasm of the students was
unbounded and was displayed by
the large number of upper classmen present.
A similar but larger celebration
will take place on the eve of the
Maryland State game. On this occasion it is hoped that every
undergraduate will be present,
since the State rooters expect to
turn out in force.

JOHNS HOPKINS PRESS
ANNONCES NEW
PUBLICATION.
The John Hopkins University
announces the establishment of a
new publication entitled "The
Johns Hopkins University Studies
in Education." The studies will
include monographs presenting
the results of investigation carried on at the University and elsewhere, which, because of their importance, should appear as separate units at once. They will be
edited by Prof. Edward F. Buckner, head of the Educational Department, with the co-operation
of Dr. C. Macfie Campbell. The
Johns Hopkins Press will get out
only a limited edition at first.
There will be a discount for advance orders if subscription is
made before the edition goes to
press.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 16 1920
BUILDING OF DORMITORIES DELAYED BY LACK
OF FUNDS.
Alumni Drive Only Partially Successful—Pledges Should be Paid as
Soon as Possible.

The erection of the first Dormitory Unit now depends on the
raising of the necessary funds
without increasing the outstanding debt of the University. The
Trustees are not now in a position to begin work until the necessary funds are clearly in sight,
and think; moreover, that as the
high point in construction work
has been passed, the building may
be erected next spring for decidedly less than the $450,000
estimate made last year.
The Alumni drive for $300,000
has been only partially successful,
since only $224,000 in pledges has
been secured, despite the untiring
efforts of the committee. A request for the payment of all subscriptions is now being made;
everyone who contributed is therefore urged to send either the total
amount of his pledge or the first
of the five yearly payments to the
Treasurer of the University as
soon as possible.
The Advisory Board has now
passed on and approved Mr. Edward Palmer's plans for the exterior of the building, and has
authorized him to call for bids
from contractors. Much difficulty
is being experienced in deciding
on the interior arrangements. A
careful study will be made by the
type of men who attend the University and who will use the dormitory, of their financial standing
and of the preferences and prejudices which they are apt to possess. It will then be determined
whether single or double rooms
are to be provided, and whether
to arrange for individual studies
or for a large assembly hall. Uncertainty also exists as to whether
or not to provide accommodation
for the fraternity chapters, or to
allow them to continue to occupy
their own houses. On none of these
questions has a definite decision
been made.
The advantages of having a dormitory at the University are selfevident. It will bring the undergraduates together at a common
meeting place, and will aid materially in increasing college spirit.
Moreover, many men will be enabled to attend Hopkins who could
not do so otherwise. No college
is complete without adequate dormitories.

Johns Hopkins' Cross-Country
Team defeated Delaware College
and Maryland State at Newark,
Del., Saturday. The scores were:
Johns Hopkins, 26 Delaware, 32;
while Maryland State was left in
the lurch, with a total of 87
points. The race ivas run over
newly-tarred roads and was a
gruelling test for the men who will
represent Hopkins at the S. A. I.
A. A. cross-country championship
next week.
So fast was the pace set by Delaware's star runner, Booth, who
was runner-up to Larry Shields in
the inter-allied games, and so
• keenly was the race contested by
Hopkins and Delaware that Maryland State's best runner could get
only eleventh place. Booth covered the course in 28 minutes and
52 seconds, thus bettering his own
time by nearly a minute. Millikin,
Hopkins' captain, ran a corking
,
race, finally losing to the longlegged Booth, but beating out Wilson, the Delaware captain. Wilson was hard pushed for third by
Milligan, whose mile-running last
year marked him as a future star
for Hopkins.

two Hopkins rookies, Holsopple
and Somerville, who ran a dead

ST. JOHNS 0

Worst Defeat Ever Administered to Cadets by Black
and Blue—Markell and Jones Star for Hopkins
Freshman Defeat Severn in Preliminary Game
The Black and Blue football team, displaying a crushing attack
and a stone wall defense, last Saturday beat St. John's, 41 to 0, and
sent them home with the worst defeat they have ever received from
Hopkins.
Before the game was five minutes old it became clear that it was
merely a question of how many points Hopkins would roll up, for the
Cadets were unable either to halt their opponents' offensive or to do
anything at all with the ball themselves. The St. John's rooters were
forced to display all their enthusiasm before the game.
Preceding the Hopkins steam roller and the coffin with its funeral
procession, they marched upon the field with a great show of confidence,
but to no avail; from the referee's first whistle the day belonged to
Hopkins.
John Markell and Elmer Jones occupied the limelight most of the
time,for each one was in the game with all he had. Nothing could stop
Markell when, with fine interference, he skirted the ends or skimmed
the tackles for gains that were seldom less than 10 yards. Such work
would have been enough to'set him apart, but in addition he outpunfed
the St. John's hooters, threw a forward pass, intercepted one and
knocked down several more.
Jones also had little difficulty in smashing through the Cadets'
line for long gains, and when St. John's ,had the ball, showed what was,
without a doubt, the best defensive game he has ever played, and that is
saying a good deal. The outstanding play of the game was his dash
of 60 yards through the St. John's team at the beginning of the second
half.
The play of the Black and Blue
was anything but individual; Hopkins had a team on the field, a
team that worked as a unit and
made few mistakes. The line held
the Cadets to two first downs, and
time and again seemed to bury
the Annapolitans under a heap of
black jerseys, while the backfield
rolled up six touchdowns and 25
first downs with a display of coordination and snioothness they
have never, before possessed. Perfect interference was the only
thing that made possible many of
the long gains, and in this interference Jones played a leading
Part. Forward passes, although
not at all needed, were used effectively.• Markell's punts were
long, and the ends were down under them with a speed that caught
the receiver before he had a chance
to move. There were no weak
spots in the machine.
The game was only a succession
of marches down the field by the
Black, and Blue steam roller,
which always ended in a score,
even though temporarily halted.
Gaining the ball in the first few
minutes, Hopkins worked it to the
goal line, only to lose it by what

seemed a poor decision. In a, moment, however, they were right
back, and Jones had scored the
first coUnter. In the second quarter he again carried the ball over,
after Markell's 20-yard plunge
through the line had placed it under the goal posts. Twice more
Hopkins threatened to score, but
each time was robbed of the opportunity to roll up the count by
a fumble.
The second half saw a great
weakening in the St. John's team.
Markell and Jones continued to
reel off the first downs, aided now
and then by a forward pass. Several times St. John's held, but it
was only for the moment, and
soon the ball was deep in their territory again.
Hopkins had
amassed 41 points, and was on its
way to another when the game
ended.
The contest with the Cadets
marked still another stage in the
gradual development of the Black
and Blue, which has been marked
in the last three games. If this
improvement continues, Western
Maryland has little chance next
Saturday and State will have its

Tentative Petition Drawn Up—Criticism and Alterations Invited.
Petition to be Presented at
Mass-meeting.

The following tentative petition
has been drawn up to be presented
at a student mass-meeting on
Thursday, November 18. It provides for a non-athletic fee to be
levied in the same manner as the
present athletic fee, and provides
for a central control of all the non'athletic activities, at the same
time taking away from these activities none of their rightful
powers. Such a plan has been
worked with great success at
many other institutions. •
The plan is purely tentative,
and it is hoped that it will call
forth a great deal of discussion between now and the mass-meeting.
A.11 who are interested and desire
to suggest alterations or additions
to the proposal are urged to leave
them at the NEWS-LETTER office
before 5 P. M. Wednesday.
If passed by the student-body at
the mass-meeting the revised petition will be presented to the
Trustees, with a request urging
them to take action on it as soon
as possible. The petition in its
tentative form is as follows:
"Resolved, That we, the studentbody of Johns Hopkins University,
request the Board of Trustees to
establish a fee of $10 to be devoted
to non-athletic activities, which
fee is to be paid by each student
upon entrance to the University,
as is the present athletic fee.
"That this fee shall be turned
over to the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, to be divided among the

ATHLETIC STORE MOVES.
The Johns Hopkins Athletic
Store has just been moved to
larger and more convenient quarters in the Students' Activity
Building in the old barber shop
on the ground floor. It is here
that one can buy athletic goods
of all varieties and the best quality. McCallister's sporting goods
are on display there and whatever
the main store has can be gotten
easily and quickly. The Athletic
Association maintains this store
in order that men can get their
supplies which are needed without the trouble of going downtown to get them. Purchasing
things there also helps to put a
man through college. It is always
open from 12.30 to 1 and after
laboratory in the afternoon.
Joe Thompson has a large supply of megaphones substantially
made up in black and blue. Every
man ought to have one of these to
assist in the rooting at these next
two games. Those who are working for track can secure sweat
shirts and winter running clothes
which will surpass any that can
be bought downtown. All Hopkins men should look into the supply at the Athletic Store before
Purchasing elsewhere — it will
help both.

In a recent letter to the Unigersity Y. M. C. A., President
3utler of Columbia said:
"It seems to me that any University which does not give proper
and central place to the religious
life and religious influence can
hardly claim to be an educational
institution. It may give most excellent instruction and it may
foster research; but with that
lack it will never be able to truly
educate."

TO INSPECT UNIT TODAY.
The E. 0. T. C. Unit will be inspected today by two distinguished
officers from Washington, Maj.Gen. William G. Haan and Col.
Frank J. Morrow. General Haan
is Assistant to Chief of Staff, War
Plans Division, and commanded
the 32d Division during the war.
Colonel Morrow is in the War
Plans Division of the General
Staff. The Unit will have classroom work during the inspection
and no formal review or military
exercises are contemplated.

day, November 10, three new men
appeared on the campus — men
whom the students should become
acquainted with from whose experience in the various fields of
life they should profit.
Dr. W. H. Morgan who leads
the Freshman class group, was
at the age of nine, a mill boy in
an Ohio steel mill. At the age of
majority he could neither read nor
write. His self-education began
with the finding of a history and a
geography. Today he has the degrees of A. B., A. M., Ph. D. and
D. D. Formerly pastor of one of
the largest Methodist Episcopal
churches in the world, Calvary
Church, New York City, he is now
pastor of the First M. E. Church
of this city.
Mr. Carey for 30 years treasurer of the Provident Savings
Bank subsequently with the Morriss Apartment Corporation, has
had wide experience with men in
the business world and is ably
fitted to make the Senior-Junior •
Forum interesting and profitable.
Mr. Morriss for 38 years general secretary of the Central Y. M.
C. A., has given his life to work
with and for young men. One of
the most widely influential men
in Baltimore life, he knows men
and understands sympathetically
their questions.
It is hoped that the studentbody will avail itself of this opportunity of extending its knowledge and interest in the life and
work of the world.

Defeating such a fine team is,

OLD - TIME "PEP"
DISPLAYED.
Much of the old-time "pep" and
spirit of rivalry against St. Johns
was manifested by the huge bonfire at Homewood and the parade
through the town in which some
300 students participated. The
bonfire and parade were in accord
with old Hopkins' traditions. The
enthusiasm of the students was
unbounded and was displayed by
the large number of upper classmen present.
A similar but larger celebration
will take place on the eve of the
Maryland State game. On this occasion it is hoped that every
undergraduate will be present,
since the State rooters expect to
turn out in force.

JOHNS HOPKINS PRESS
ANNONCES NEW
PUBLICATION.
The John Hopkins University
announces the establishment of a
new publication entitled "The
Johns Hopkins University Studies
in Education." The studies will
include monographs presenting
the results of investigation carried on at the University and elsewhere, which, because of their importance, should appear as separate units at once. They will be
edited by Prof. Edward F. Buckner, head of the Educational Department, with the co-operation
of Dr. C. Macfie Campbell. The
Johns Hopkins Press will get out
only a limited edition at first.
There will be a discount for advance orders if subscription is
made before the edition goes to

American

Delta Kappa Endorses
Non-Athletic Fee.

Editor of the News-Letter:
Sir—At the last meeting of the
Beta Circle of American Delta
Kappa a resolution was unanimously passed endorsing the proposed fee for non-athletic activities.
The Circle feels that a non-athletic fee is as indispensable as the
athletic fee.
Very truly yours,
R. GRAHAM HEINER,
President.
The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—In regard to the proposed non-athletic fee I would like
to say that I consider the idea an
excellent one and worthy of the
best backing possible by every student at the University.
Yours truly,
Wm. H. WOOD.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 16 1920
BUILDING OF DORMITORIES DELAYED BY LACK
OF FUNDS.
Alumni Drive Only Partially Successful—Pledges Should be Paid as
Soon as Possible.

The erection of the first Dormitory Unit now depends on the
raising of the necessary funds
without increasing the outstanding debt of the University. The
Trustees are not now in a position to begin work until the necessary funds are clearly in sight,
and think; moreover, that as the
high point in construction work
has been passed, the building may
be erected next spring for decidedly less than the $450,000
estimate made last year.
The Alumni drive for $300,000
has been only partially successful,
since only $224,000 in pledges has
been secured, despite the untiring
efforts of the committee. A request for the payment of all subscriptions is now being made;
everyone who contributed is therefore urged to send either the total
amount of his pledge or the first
of the five yearly payments to the
Treasurer of the University as
soon as possible.
The Advisory Board has now
passed on and approved Mr. Edward Palmer's plans for the exterior of the building, and has
authorized him to call for bids
from contractors. Much difficulty
is being experienced in deciding
on the interior arrangements. A
careful study will be made by the
type of men who attend the University and who will use the dormitory, of their financial standing
and of the preferences and prejudices which they are apt to possess. It will then be determined
whether single or double rooms
are to be provided, and whether
to arrange for individual studies
or for a large assembly hall. Uncertainty also exists as to whether
or not to provide accommodation
for the fraternity chapters, or to
allow them to continue to occupy
their own houses. On none of these
questions has a definite decision
been made.
The advantages of having a dormitory at the University are selfevident. It will bring the undergraduates together at a common
meeting place, and will aid materially in increasing college spirit.
Moreover, many men will be enabled to attend Hopkins who could
not do so otherwise. No college
is complete without adequate dormitories.

The 0. D. had satisfied himself
concerning Post No. One's work of
the evening when he suddenly bethought himself.

"I ain't got none," replied Post

Private Binks was incorrigible.
His disposition had always been
too merry and carefree to suit the
C. 0., but when he entered the P.
C. whistling, it was altogether too
much.
"Binks," said the captain sternly, "you seem to like to whistle.
I'll give you your chance. Stand
there in the corner and whistle
for one hour."
Privatq Binks swung into the
strains of "The Star-Spangled
Banner."
"Your sentence is mitigated to
five minutes," said the captain,
rising wearily to attention.
—American Legion Weekly.

PLAYLETS TO BE PRESENTED ON TWENTYTHIRD.
This Date Set for First Production of
Dramatic Club—Public Cordially
Invited—Admission TwentyFive Cents.

The date for the production of
the first series of small playlets of
the Dramatic Club has been set
for Tuesday, November 23, at 8.15
P. M. The playlets will be presented in the studio in the upper
story of the Barn. The propertymen have been at work rigging up
crude scenery which will harmonize with the Bohemian atmosphere
of the room.
E. S. Bashfprd's play, "Three
Friends," will be given first. Its
cast includes the following:
The Boy.
Joe Moran, '23
E. F. Buchner, '23,
Tilt Mother.
Glover Fallon, '23,
The Spirit of the Night.
Holzappel, '24,
The Spirit of the Brook.
This play is a phantasy, depicting
the beauties of nature and its
realization in an artist's painting.
Joe Moran's playlet, "Triangle
Extraordinary," will have a cast
including:
H. P. Brawner, '23...Lester.
Messersmith, '24,
Margaret Graham.
Junifer, '24
George.
G. L. Sadtler, '23
Boggs.
The scene of the play is in Lester's drawing-room, where he and

Margaret are contemplating a
scheme to get her a divorce from
her husband. It ends in a pistol
duel.
The admisSion will be but 25
cents. The Club finds it necessary
to. charge this fee which will be
hardly enough to cover expenses.
If the room is crowded on November 23, the plays will be repeated
the night following. All the students of the University who are interested in the Club's activities are
invited to attend this presentation.

)THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 16, 1920
NON-ATHLETIC FEE SUGGESTED
(Concluded from page 1)

different non-athletic activities as
it sees fit, subject to the approval
of the chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee.
"That a uniform system of accounts for all non-athletic activities be adopted under the supervision of the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, and that these accounts
be open at all times to inspection
by the Chairman of the Student
Affairs Committee and such committees as the faculty or studentbody see fit to appoint.
"Tile advantages of such a system are as follows:
"1. It insures to non-athletic
activities the support which they
have failed to receive in the past.
"2. It thus enables them to
cover a greater field than before.
"3. It places the burden of support equally on all students.
"4. It - thus arouses interest
throughout the entire studentbody.
"5. It saves the non-athletic activities hundreds of dollars and
hours of labor spent in the past
on the collection of money.
"6. It provides a centralized
system of accounts open to inspection at all times.
"7. It will eliminate profit on
the part of members of the various organizations.
"We suggest the disbursement
of the fund be arranged as follows: Hullabaloo, $3; News-Letter (which will appear twice a
week next year), $2; Daily Bulletin, 50 cents • Dramatic Club,
$1.75; Musical Club, 50 cents;
Debating Council, 25 cents; Y. M.
C. A.,$1; Hopkins Black and Blue
Jay, $1.
"In return for this assessment
the student is to receive a copy of
the Hullabaloo, a subscription to
the News-Letter and Daily Bulletin, $2 ticket (or the equivalent)
to one of the performances of the
Dramatic Club, a ticket to a performance given by the Musical
Club at Homewood, tickets to all
debates and a subscription to the
Hopkins Black and Blue Jay.
"We further recommend. that
the profits of each organization be
handed in to the Varsity Seal Voting Council at the end of the year,
to be credited to that organization
for the following year."
